text: hi Jeff John from food wishes comm with
a an idea here for what to do after your
4th of July barbecue we're going to do
hot smoked salmon and we're basically
going to use the leftover coals from
your hot dogs and your hamburgers and
your tri-tip whatever you did barbecuing
but you got to think ahead
alright soak these wood chips overnight
minimum minimum one hour in the water
otherwise we'll start on fire and you'll
have all kinds of noxious fumes and you
don't want that so soak some wood chips
what I did is I made a little kind of
pan out of four or five layers of heavy
duty aluminum foil
I tried to make it about the same size
as the salmon and I just crimped up the
edges so that's pretty easy to do I
I should have filmed that but I did but
you can do it it's not very complicated
just fold up some foil alright and what
you're going to do there I put on two I
don't know five six ounces of wild
alaskan salmon skin side down just a
little salt and pepper and let that come
to room temperature okay you don't want
this ice cold now what I mean by using
leftover coals the chickens been
barbecue the tri-tips long since been
eaten hot dogs hamburgers some some
crazy hippies even grilled some garden
burgers on here anyway we're done the
clothes are almost burnt out but not
quite there's still some heat no see
they're completely white they're on
their last legs so what you do is you
push them all the way to the sides and
by the way I'm using my beautiful 15
year old Weber grill here
and I took about two handfuls of those
very well soaked chips now traditionally
you want to use a sweet wood like an
apple wood or a Hickory up north here in
Northern California there's some people
even used the the you know grapevines
and use what you want so you're going to
put about two handfuls of those soaked
chips around and in the middle of those
coals put the grill back on now when you
first put the the chips on you're going
to think you have smoke but you don't
you have steam and steam is not what you
want right away so give it about five or
six minutes see that steam and then I'll
sudden the water the drippy water will
be gone and they'll still be wet but now
they're going to start to smoke and you
can smell it you can actually smell when
that starts to happen as soon as you can
smell that smoke and see a good amount
of smoke being generated grab your
salmon and you're simply just going to
slide it off the plate into the center
of that grill that's why we pushed all
the coals to the side we don't want any
direct Heat we want this to cook kind of
slow I want this to take about you know
1215 minutes if it cooks too fast and
we're just gonna have big salmon and it
won't absorb the smoke close the vents
alright close the vents we want this to
go nice and slow by the way I did clean
the top of the grill it's just like I
said it's about 15 years old and doesn't
look nice but it's okay alright so take
the lid off that was after about five
minutes I just wanted to peek it wasn't
done put it back on
all right it's been about 10 minutes now
I'm going to start to check more often I
feel it with my finger it is it's
starting to get warm but I can tell it's
still not cooked it's almost there so
you starting to flake a little bit by
the way when you're smoking or
barbecuing and you hear fire engines
sound like they're starting to pull up
to your house
that's never a good sign
thank God it was the neighbors so anyway
I put the lid back on this needs a
couple more minutes and then it was done
see I can feel the the Sam is actually
kind of hot the juices and oils have
come to the top I am going to take that
off and here's where I kind of screwed
up this shot was way too tight what I
did is I took the plate and the tongs
and I just slid it back on there so let
me cheat here let me reverse the shot of
me putting it on the grill and and again
the tongs were actually on the other
side but use your imagination just slide
it back on your plate another good
reason to make sure you have at least
four or five layers of foil doubled up I
serve it simply see smoked hot smoked
salmon very rich that smoke flavor
really permeates salmon as you know is
oily and delicious fish those oils are
great for you by the way so just a
squeeze of fresh lemon some greens some
of my lime and Chipotle a sweet potatoes
I was in heaven
so this came out really really nice I
was extremely happy
it by the way go to the blog read the
